required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Biobehavioral Impact of Diet Quality on Affect and Craving
clinical_study.official_title: The Biobehavioral Impact of Diet Quality on Affect and Craving

brief_summary.textblock:
The current study experimentally investigates whether reducing highly processed foods (defined in this study as foods high in added sugars) leads to biological, psychological, and / or behavioral indicators of withdrawal. The following hypotheses are tested:
1. To test the hypothesis that reducing highly processed food intake will result in higher daily reports of physical (e.g. physical), cognitive (e.g. difficulty concentrating), and affective (e.g., irritability) withdrawal symptoms.
2. To test the hypothesis that reducing highly processed food intake will result in increased negative affect (negative mood) as indicated by biological (heart rate) and psychological (self - reported distress ratings; daily emotion / mood reports) measures.
3. To test the hypothesis that reducing highly processed food intake will result in increased response to environmental cues for highly processed food as indicated by biological (neural response from fMRI scan; heart rate measures), psychological (self - report craving measures), and behavioral measures.
Participants come to the University of Michigan Psychology department three times for in lab appointments. Several daily questionnaires are completed at home between in lab visits. The initial in lab visit is to confirms eligibility, sign consent, and get baseline measurements (questionnaires, in lab tasks, body composition measurements). After the initial visit, participants start an active assessment period (pre / post dietary change assessments) Pre - dietary change includes at home questionnaires while eating a typical diet and a lab visit. The Post dietary change lab assessment includes at home questionnaires while consuming 3 days of food portion lower in highly processed foods and an in lab assessment. The pre and post in lab assessments each include an fMRI scan, computer tasks, questionnaires, collecting heart rate data, and taking height and body composition measurements.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Multi-method, within subjects, prospective, experimental design

primary_outcome.measure: Change as indicators of physical withdrawal symptoms using heart rate monitoring
primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 1 month
primary_outcome.description: Physical symptoms are assessed using heart rate monitoring (using heart rate belt strapped around chest) during the pre / post in - lab assessments. Data are collected in a simulated fast food restaurant and while completing a stress task where they listen to a recording of a stressful event. Change in heart rate pre dietary change compared to post dietary change within subjects will be used for analyses.

primary_outcome.measure: Change as indicator of physical withdrawal symptoms using fMRI scan
primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 1 month
primary_outcome.description: Physical symptoms are assessed using fMRI scans completed at the pre / post in lab assessments to assess reward response to highly processed food (chocolate milkshake). Participants are given small amounts of water and milkshake. Pictures of a glass of water or a milkshake are shown while participants are in the scanner. Participants are asked to anticipate what is in the picture. After seeing the picture and anticipating the taste the participant receives a small amount of the pictured liquid to drink. Change in brain response pre dietary change compared to post dietary change will be used for analyses.

primary_outcome.measure: Change as indicator of affective withdrawal symptom using subjective craving measure
primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 1 month
primary_outcome.description: Affective withdrawal symptoms are measured by asking participants to self-report subjective cravings during the fMRI scan, simulated restaurant task, and stress task. Participants are asked to give a rate of current craving for food on a scale of 0 to 100. Participants are asked to complete this measures before and after each task during the pre and post dietary change lab assessments. Change in self - report responses of subjective craving at pre dietary change compared to post dietary change will be used for analyses.

primary_outcome.measure: Change as indicator of affective withdrawal symptom using subjective hunger measure
primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 1 month
primary_outcome.description: Affective withdrawal symptoms are measured by asking participants to self-report subjective hunger during the fMRI scan, simulated restaurant task, and stress task. Participants are asked to give a rate of current hunger on a scale of 0 to 100. Participants are asked to complete these measures before and after each task during the pre and post dietary change lab assessments. Change in self - report responses of subjective hunger at pre dietary change compared to post dietary change will be used for analyses.

primary_outcome.measure: Change as indicator of affective withdrawal symptom using Positive and Negative Affect Scale
primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 1 month
primary_outcome.description: Affective withdrawal symptoms are measured by asking participants to complete the Positive and Negative Affect Scale (PANAS) which asked about current feeling / emotions. Response options are "very slightly / not at all" "a little" "moderately" "quite a bit" or "extremely." Participants are asked to complete these measures before and after each task during the pre and post dietary change lab assessments. Change in self - report responses on the PANAS at pre dietary change compared to post dietary change will be used for analyses.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in food cue reactivity using heart rate monitoring
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 1 month
secondary_outcome.description: Participants are brought into a simulated fast food restaurant during the pre and post lab assessments. The restaurant is a cue - rich environment designed to simulate the experience of being in a fast food restaurant (i.e. smell of french fries, large monitors displaying menus, condiments counter, etc.) A tray of highly processed food items (e.g. french fries, burger, milkshake) will be available where the participant is seated, but the participant will not be allowed to eat the food. Participant's heart rate (using heart rate belt strapped around chest). Change in heart rate pre dietary change compared to post dietary change within subjects will be used for analyses.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in food cue reactivity using self - report questionnaire
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 1 month
secondary_outcome.description: Participants will be brought into a simulated fast food restaurant during the pre and post lab assessments. The restaurant is a cue - rich environment designed to simulate the experience of being in a fast food restaurant (i.e. smell of french fries, large monitors displaying menus, condiments counter, etc.) A tray of highly processed food items (e.g. french fries, burger, milkshake) will be available where the participant is seated, but the participant will not be allowed to eat the food. Participant's subjective hunger and craving will be measured on a scale of 0 to 100. Change is self - report responses on these self - report measures while in the cue - rich environment during the pre dietary change compared to post dietary change will be used for analyses.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Pre and Post Dietary Change (within subjects)
arm_group.description: Participants do an in - lab screening to confirm eligibility and collect baseline data. Then the active assessment period (pre / post dietary change) begins. Pre - dietary change procedure is 3 days of standard high HP diet while completing daily electronic assessments of withdrawal (Highly Processed Food Withdrawal Scale) and then a laboratory assessment. Post - dietary change is 3 days of lower HP diet (food portions will be provided) while completing daily electronic assessments and then a laboratory assessment. The electronic daily assessments are assessements of affect, craving and withdrawal symptoms measured by the Highly Processed Food Withdrawal Scale (ProWS). The pre / post-dietary change lab assessments entail 1) fMRI protocol to assess reward-response to a HP food 2) cue reactivity task in a simulated fast food restaurant, 3) psychosocial stress task, and 4) body composition / BMI assessment.

intervention.intervention_name: Dietary Change (low in highly processed foods)
intervention.description: Food is provided to participant for 3 days. The University of Michigan's Nutrition Obesity Research Center (NORC)'s Metabolic Kitchen prepares the food. The low HP food diet is based on prior methods where participants are placed on an isocaloric diet composed of 5% or less of calories from added sugar and 10% or less of overall calories from total sugar. No foods that meet the criteria for a HP food based (defined by Kant and colleagues) that corresponds to: sweeteners (sugar, candy, etc); carbonated and non-carbonated beverages (fruit drinks, sweetened / diet beverages, etc. ); baked / dairy desserts (cookies, pies, ice cream, etc.); salted snacks (potato chips, etc.) and fast foods (pizza, cheeseburgers, French fries, etc.) are included in the diet portions. The overall macro nutrient composition of the diet will be approximately 20-25% of kcal from protein, 30-35% of kcal from fat, and 40-50% of kcal from carbohydrates.
intervention.arm_group_label: Pre and Post Dietary Change (within subjects)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age 25 to 40
- Overweight (self report BMI of 24.50 to 33.99, measured BMI of 25.00 to 34.99)
- Moderately or Highly motivated to eat a healthier diet
- Mild, moderate or sever levels of addictive like eating (2 or higher on the Yale Food Addiction Scale)
- Fluent in english
- Willing to follow dietary guidelines provided by study team and eat only provide food for 3 days. Willing to delay dietary change until instructed to do so
- Likes the taste of chocolate milkshake
Exclusion Criteria:
- fMRI exclusion criteria (metal implants / metal in body, claustrophobia, surgery in the past 8 weeks, etc.)
- Weight fluctuation of 20+ pounds in the last 3 months
- Attempted weight loss using a formal weight loss program (e.g. weight watchers) in the last month
- Prior weight loss surgery (e.g. bariatric surgery)
- Medications or medical conditions that may impact study results such as medications that impact appetite, heart rate, or reward functioning (e.g. taking synthroid or has diabetes)
- Current major psychiatric diagnoses (e.g., anxiety, depression, bipolar, schizophrenia, substance use disorder, eating disorder)
- A past diagnosis of a restrictive eating disorder (anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, purging disorder)
- Significant dietary restrictions (e.g. allergies, veganism)
- currently pregnant, breastfeeding, trying to get pregnant, or within 6 months of giving birth
- high levels of alcohol (i.e. daily consumption) and / or caffeine (average daily consumption over 500mg)
- meeting criteria for clinically significant alcohol consumption on the CAGE alcohol assessment

patient_data.ipd_description: Individual participant data that underlie the results reported will be de-identified and shared.
patient_data.ipd_time_frame: Beginning 3 months and ending 5 years following article publication
patient_data.ipd_access_criteria: Researchers who provide a methodologically sound proposal will be able to access data to achieve aims outlined in the approved proposal. Proposals should be directed to agearhar@umich.edu to gain access. Data requestors will need to sign a data access agreement. Data will be stored by the research team for 5 years.
